newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Moroccan foreign debt $22 billion end '96 - minister.
newsitem.headline: Moroccan foreign debt $22 billion end '96 - minister.

text.p: Despite an expected drop in Morocco's public foreign debt drop to $22 billion at the end of this year from 1995. Morocco's finance minister said the debt will still weigh heavily on the economy.
In remarks published in Le Matin du Sahara on Wednesday, Mohamed Kabbaj said the debt had been cut by three billion dirhams ($340 million) from 1995.
"The charges of the debt, despite their drop, continue to weigh heavily on the national economy," he said.

"Payments of principal and interest should reach 26 billion dirhams in 1996 compared to 29.9 billion dirhams in 1995," he said, adding that compared to current balance of payments receipts, debt service represented 25 percent against 33 percent last year.
"In relation to gross national product, the outstanding debt represents 60 percent against 69 percent in 1995 and 123 percent in 1985," the minister added.
Morocco was restructuring its debt. Some had been converted into private investment, with part of the debt with France totalling 600 million French francs ($115 million).
"Out of this, some 218.1 million have already been allocated and concern seven projects which should generate a total investment of 760 million dirhams."
The same had been done with Spain for some $50 million worth of debt.
"This mechanism brings two advantages. It enables us, at the same time, to attract foreign investments by reducing their financing cost and also reduces outstanding Moroccan debt," he said.
There was also a French loan of 1.5 billion francs, partly guaranteed by France, and the "cancellation-conversion" of 400 million francs into public investment.
The conversion value of this in dirhams was being put into a fund for development projects in the north of Morocco.

Internal debt, which the minister said had taken an important place in Treasury financing, rose to 102.5 billion dirhams at the end of last November, a rise of 6.9 percent compared with the end of December 1995.
